questions.text: Two bubbles X and Y have the same surface tension, but bubble X has 2 times the diameter of bubble Y. The ratio of the pressure in bubble X to that in bubble Y is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

0.5:1

According to La Place’s Law, Tension = Distending pressure * radius or Pressure = T/r. in other words, the distending pressure is inverse to the radius. 

Bubble X, which has 2 times the radius of bubble Y, will therefore, have half of the pressure in bubble Y.

choices.text: Myelinated axons would show a decreased conduction velocity, and unmyelinated axons would show an increased conduction velocity.
Myelinated axons would show an increased conduction velocity, and unmyelinated axons would show a decreased conduction velocity.
Myelinated axons would show an increased conduction velocity, and unmyelinated axons would show an increased conduction velocity.
Myelinated axons would show a decreased conduction velocity, and unmyelinated axons would show no change in conduction velocity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to her physician complaining of difficulty in walking. On questioning, the patient indicates she had trouble walking for 5 days last month and also that she has experienced pain and prickly sensations that come and go, as well as occasional muscle weakness. Vital Signs: T 36.5°C, P 70/min, R 15/min, BP 124/80 mm Hg, BMI 27. Muscle strength testing: Normal. Deep tendon reflexes: Normal. When asked to walk, the patient had difficulty in balancing and maintaining a normal gait. Patellar tendon reflexes were normal. The muscles, however, were weak. LABORATORY STUDIES- MRI indicated Gd-enhancing brain lesions, as well as one infratentorial lesion and three periventricular lesions in the brain. Analysis of cerebrospinal fluid showed an oligoclonal IgG band. During the initial stages of this disease, how would the velocity of action potential transmission be altered within the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Myelinated axons would show a decreased conduction velocity, and unmyelinated axons would show no change in conduction velocity.

Multiple sclerosis is thought to be an autoimmune disease that leads to loss of myelin from central nervous system axons. The lost myelin is replaced by scar tissue called sclerosis. The central nervous system damage results in multiple lesions that are visible on magnetic resonance imaging. Demyelinating diseases diminish the speed of axonal transmission. Consequently, this negatively impacts the coordinated and sequential activation of motor neurons necessary for walking. The difficulty in walking is likely due to damage to the myelinated axons of the basal ganglia or the cerebellum. Deep tendon reflexes are normal because the neuromuscular transmission is working normally in the early stage of the disease. Similarly, muscle weakness may not be apparent. However, over time, the degeneration of the nerves will lead to muscle atrophy and weakness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has a mass in the sella turcica that compresses the portal vessels, disrupting pituitary access to hypothalamic secretions. The secretion rate of which hormone would most likely increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prolactin

Prolactin secretion is inhibited by hypothalamic PIF. All others are stimulated by hypothalamic hormones.  Obstruction of blood flow through the hypothalamic- hypophyseal portal vessels would lead to reduced secretion of ACTH, TSH, GH, FSH, LH, but increased secretion of Prolactin

choices.text: It produces its effect by activating cAMP
It produces its effect by increasing the distal tubular permeability to sodium
It causes an increased secretion of hydrogen ions
It is secreted in response to decrease in blood pressure

questions.text: A/E the following characterize the production and actions of aldosterone in the body-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aldosterone binds to an intracytoplasmic receptor that causes an increased synthesis of proteins, including the Na+- K+ ATPase pumps, ENaCs, K+ channels, which together increase the sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the tubular cells of the distal nephron. Aldosterone also increases the H+ secretion in the distal nephron. Aldosterone secretion is stimulated by a decrease in blood volume (through the renin- angiotensin system) and by an increased plasma K+ concentration.

questions.text: The transport of H+ ions into the proximal tubule is primarily associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reabsorption of bicarbonate

In the PCT, for every H+ ion secreted, one bicarbonate is reabsorbed (indirect reabsorption of bicarbonate).

choices.text: Urinary excretion rate of that substance

questions.text: The maximum clearance rate possible for a substance that is totally cleared from the plasma is equal to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Renal plasma flow

If a substance is totally cleared from the plasma, then its clearance rate will be equal to the renal plasma flow. In other words, the total amount of the substance delivered to the kidneys (renal plasma flow X plasma concentration of the substance) would be equal to the amount excreted in the urine. PAH in low concentration is freely filtered and completely secreted and its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is found comatose in her kitchen by her husband and is brought to the Emergency of a nearby hospital. Blood gas analysis reveals normal Po2 and a lower-than-normal arterial O2 saturation. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with the findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CO poisoning

A normal Po2 and lower-than-normal So2 is indicative of anemic hypoxia. CO poisoning causes anemic hypoxia.

choices.text: Transport of glucose from the intestinal lumen into intestinal epithelial cell is by secondary active co-transport
Transport of glucose into adipocytes is by facilitated diffusion
Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-dependent counter transport
Movement of Na++ ions into a nerve cell during the upstroke phase of the action potential is by facilitated diffusion

questions.text: Given below are four examples of transport across the cell membrane with the type of transport. Which of the following is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal epithelial cells is by Na+- glucose co-transport, an example of secondary active co-transport. 

Glucose is transported into adipocytes by insulin-dependent facilitated diffusion. 

Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-Ca++ antiport, which is an example of secondary active counter transport. 

During the depolarization phase of the action potential opening of voltage gated sodium channels allows the influx of sodium. Transport through channels is an example of simple diffusion.

questions.text: Which of the following points in the cardiac muscle action potential is close to the equilibrium potential of potassium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

At rest the cell membrane is maximally permeable to potassium. Therefore, the potential at A will be the closest to the equilibrium potential of potassium. The upstroke of the cardiac action potential is due to the influx of sodium through voltage gated sodium channels. Point B will, therefore, be closest to the equilibrium potential of sodium.

questions.text: Which of the following reflexes is correctly paired with its receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Autogenic inhibition- Golgi tendon organ

Receptors for the stretch reflex (also k/a myotactic reflex or deep tendon jerk) are the muscle spindles. Reciprocal inhibition is also mediated by the muscle spindles. Receptors for the inverse stretch reflex (also k/a autogenic inhibition) are the Golgi tendon organs

questions.text: An increase in the shear stress in a blood vessel is likely to cause which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased NO production

An increase in shear stress in blood vessels is one of the main stimuli for the release of NO by endothelial cells. NO increases blood flow by increasing cGMP.

questions.text: If a person has been exercising for one hour which of the following will have the smallest decrease in blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Brain

After exercising for 1 hour, the blood flow to the GI tract, kidneys, pancreas, non-exercising muscles decreases significantly but the blood flow to the brain remains close to its control value.

questions.text: SCFA absorption occurs almost exclusively form which of the following segments of the GI tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Colon

Colon is the major site of production and absorption of SCFAs. SCFAs are produced by colonic bacteria which act on dietary fibre and undigested complex carbohydrates. In addition to having a trophic action on the colonic mucosa, they are believed to promote sodium absorption from the colon.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male has a murmur that ceases with the onset of the second heart sound. Second heart sound occurs at the onset of which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Isovolumetric relaxation

Second heart sound marks the end of systole and beginning of diastole. The first phase of diastole is the isovolumetric relaxation phase.

questions.text: If the extracellular concentration of calcium is 100mmol/L and intracellular concentration is 10 millimole/ L and 2.3RT/F = 60mV, what is the equilibrium potential of calcium (cell membrane is freely permeable to calcium)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

+30 mV

The equilibrium potential for calcium will be 60/2  log 100/10 = 60 X 1/2 = 30 mV. Calcium will move from outside to inside generating a positive potential inside. The equilibrium potential for calcium will, therefore, be +60mV.

questions.text: A group of students decide to go hiking while visiting Leh. After 3 hours, one of them becomes disoriented, ataxic, short of breath and starts vomiting. A diagnostic work-up at a nearby hospital shows a decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

PaCO2

High altitude causes a hypoxic hypoxia, which in turn stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors increasing the rate and depth of ventilation. Increase in alveolar ventilation causes a CO2 washout and respiatory alkalosis increasing the pH. Hypoxia will cause a pulmonary vasoconstriction increasing the pulmonary vascular resistance. In high altitude, glycolysis increases which in turn causes increase in 2,3- BPG.

questions.text: Both the peripheral and central chemoreceptors mediate increased ventilation in response to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypercapnia

Both the peripheral and central chemoreceptors respond to an increase in Paco2 levels. The peripheral chemoreceptors also cause an increase in ventilation in response to a decrease in arterial pH and a decrease in Pao2. The central chemoreceptors are unresponsive to hypoxemia or to a decrease in arterial pH.

choices.text: Increased water permeability of the collecting duct

questions.text: Which of the following will be found in a dehydrated individual deprived of water for 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased water permeability of the collecting duct

In a dehydrated person, plasma osmolality will increase. Increase in plasma osmolality stimulates the secretion of ADH. ADH increases insertion of aquaporin 2 in the luminal membrane of the collecting duct cells, increasing the water permeability.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of the cerebellum has a topographical representation of the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Medial and intermediate lobes 

The medial and intermediate lobes of the cerebellum have a distinct topographical representation of the body. These areas are responsible for coordinating the contraction of the muscles of the body for intended motion.

questions.text: At which point on the nerve action potential shown in the figure given below is the membrane closest to the equilibrium potential for sodium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Point A

When a stimulus is given to a nerve it causes opening of voltage gated sodium channels which increases the membrane permeability for sodium. Sodium entry into the cell causes the cell to depolarize. The potential reaches +30mV (point A), which is closest to the equilibrium potential for sodium (+60mV).

choices.text: Blood pressure and heart rate increase
Blood pressure and heart rate decrease
Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases
Blood pressure decreases and heart rate increases

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has a fall from his cycle and sustains a skull fracture which compresses the underlying brain tissue. Which of the following will occur in response to an increased intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases

Increase in intracranial pressure decreases cerebral blood flow producing CNS ischemia. This in turn increase sympathetic discharge increasing the blood pressure. Increased blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors producing a reflex bradycardia.

questions.text: The airway pressure of a normal 77-year-old man is approximately 1 cm H2O during expiration. What is his airway pressure during inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

-1 cm H2OExpansion of the chest cavity during inspiration causes the airway pressure (also k/a intrapulmonary pressure or alveolar pressure) to become sub-atmospheric, averaging about -1 cm H2O during quiet inspiration, resulting in movement of air into the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following motor pathways innervate the A gamma motor neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reticulospinal tract

Reticulospinal tracts- pontine/ excitatory and medullary/ inhibitory tracts innervate the A gamma motor neurons especially to the lower limb extensors, thereby, controlling extensor muscle tone.

questions.text: A normal 20-year-old male breathes in as much air as he can and then exhales as much air as possible. The lung volume at maximum inspiration is 6.0L, and the lung volume after maximum expiration is 1.0L. His tidal volume at rest is 0.5L, and his functional residual capacity is 3.5L. What is his vital capacity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5.0L

Forced vital capacity or vital capacity is the volume of air expired forcefully after a forceful inspiration. FVC = TLC – RV = 6.0 – 1.0 = 5.0L.

questions.text: A large dose of insulin is administered to a patient. Which of the following hormonal changes are NOT likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increase in aldosterone

Injection of Insulin leads to decrease in blood glucose. Hypoglycemia stimulates the secretion of GH, glucagon and epinephrine, all of which have counter- regulatory effects to increase the glucose levels in the blood. Hypoglycemia does not increase the aldosterone levels.

questions.text: Which condition at the S-A node will cause the heart rate to decrease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased potassium permeability
 
Increases in sodium and calcium permeability at the S-A node result in an increase in heart rate. An increased potassium permeability causes a hyperpolarization of the S-A node, which causes the heart rate to decrease.

questions.text: Listed below are the hydrostatic and oncotic pressures within a microcirculatory bed. Plasma colloid osmotic pressure = 25 mm Hg Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 25 mm Hg Interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure = −5 mm Hg Interstitial colloid osmotic pressure = 10 mm Hg. What is the net filtration pressure in mm Hg for this capillary wall?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

15 

Net filtration pressure = capillary hydrostatic pressure − plasma colloid osmotic pressure + interstitial colloid osmotic pressure − interstitial hydrostatic pressure. The rate of net fluid movement across the capillary wall is 150 ml/min. Net filtration pressure = [Pc − Πc + Πi − PI [25 − 25 + 10 − (−5)] ,  15mm Hg.

questions.text: In control conditions, flow through a blood vessel is 100 ml/min under a pressure gradient of 50 mm Hg. What would be the approximate flow through the vessel after increasing the vessel diameter to two times normal, assuming that the pressure gradient was maintained at 50 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1600 ml/min

According to Poiseuille’s law, flow through a vessel increases in proportion to the fourth power of the radius. A 2-fold increase in vessel diameter (or radius) would increase 2 to the fourth power, or 16 times normal. Thus, flow through the vessel after increasing the vessel 4 times normal would increase from 100 to 1600 ml/min.

questions.text: A healthy 22-year-old female medical student has an exercise stress test at a local health club. An increase in which of the following is most likely to occur in this woman’s skeletal muscles during exercise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

During exercise, tissue levels of carbon dioxide and lactic acid increase. These metabolites dilate blood vessels, decrease arteriolar resistance, and enhance vascular conductance and blood flow

questions.text: If a person maintains a high (150 mmol/day) potassium diet, which part of the nephron would be expected to reabsorb the most potassium? Choose the appropriate nephron site in the figure below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Approximately 65% of the filtered load of potassium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. Variations in renal excretion of potassium during change in potassium intake are achieved mainly by changes in potassium secretion in collecting tubules. With high potassium intake, the proximal tubule still reabsorbs a high fraction of the filtered load of potassium.

choices.text: Glucose is transported via passive diffusion
Co- transport is mediated with the use of carriers
Active transport is an energy dependent process

questions.text: A/E the following are true –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation- facilitated diffusion requires carrier protein but not dependent on energy.

questions.text:
One gram of mannitol was injected into a woman. After equilibration, a plasma sample
had a mannitol concentration of 0.08 g/L. During the equilibration period, 20% of the
injected mannitol was excreted in the urine. The subject’s-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mannitol is a marker substance for the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume. ECF volume = amount of mannitol/concentration of mannitol = 1 g – 0.2 g/0.08 g/L = 10 L.

choices.text: From carotid body and aortic body
Causes atrial vasoconstriction when BP increases
Causes increase in HR when BP increases
Causes decrease in HR when BP increases

questions.text: True about baroreceptor reflex is –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Baroreceptors are activated by increase in BP, these then activate vagal center and inhibit sympathetic center, decreasing HR.

questions.text: Unconscious proprioception is carried by-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Unconscious proprioception is carried by spinocerebellar tract and conscious proprioception by dorsal column tract.

questions.text: A hospitalized patient has an ejection fraction of 0.4, a heart rate of 100 beats/min, and a cardiac output of 3.6 L/min. What is the patient’s end-diastolic volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation-First, calculate stroke volume from the cardiac output and heart rate: Cardiac output =stroke volume X heart rate; thus, stroke volume= cardiac output/heart rate 3600 mL/100 beats/min = 36 mL. Then, calculate end-diastolic volume from stroke volume and ejection fraction: Ejection fraction = stroke volume/end-diastolic volume; thus end-diastolic volume = stroke volume/ejection fraction= 36.8 mL/0.4 = 90 mL.

questions.text: The efferent fiber bundle of the substantia nigra transmits dopamine to one of the following areas:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The connections between the parts of basal ganglia include a dopaminergic nigrostriatal projection from the substantia nigra pars compacta to the striatum and a corresponding GABAergic projection from the striatum to substantia nigra pars reticularis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of Na+–bile acid cotransport?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bile salts are recirculated to the liver in the enterohepatic circulation via a Na+–bile acid cotransporter located in the ileum of the small intestine.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with polydipsia, polyuria, fatigue, and headache, so a series of renal function tests are ordered. Which of the following test results would be an abnormal finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glucose is normally completely reabsorbed in the renal proximal tubule, so any clearance of glucose would be considered abnormal. Without memorizing values, one should understand whether and to which extend the listed substances are normally expected in urine due to the function of the kidneys.

questions.text: Which of the following is the physiological mechanism of TENS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gate control mechanism.

choices.text: Alveolar pressure is higher than atmospheric pressure
Intrapleural pressure is more negative than it is during expiration

questions.text: Which of the following is true during inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

During inspiration, intrapleural pressure becomes more negative than it is at rest or during expiration (when it returns to its less negative resting value). During inspiration, air flows into the lungs when alveolar pressure becomes lower (due to contraction of the diaphragm) than atmospheric pressure; if alveolar pressure were not lower than atmospheric pressure, air would not flow inward. The volume in the lungs during inspiration is the functional residual capacity (FRC) plus one tidal volume (TV).
